image.altText: A woman wearing a white head scarf glances down towards her hands

items.synopsis: When Israeli air strikes began near their home, Hana' Nayem and her family decided to flee on foot. She and more than 20 relatives have taken shelter elsewhere, but right now, nowhere in Gaza is safe.

title.children: No power, no food, and no end in sight: This is life for millions of Palestinians trapped inside Gaza

image.altText: Modern houses in leafy street in Brisbane on October 31, 2018.

items.synopsis: A national summit addressing the housing crisis has heard successive governments are to blame for getting Australians to this "flash point", and it could take up to 20 years to fix the problem.

title.children: There's no 'silver bullet' to solve the housing crisis, but a national summit ended with five ways forward

image.altText: Two volunteers wearing Yes and No campaign shirts stand next to each other with their faces cropped out.

items.synopsis: As an Aboriginal person, it feels impossible to digest the freight train of messages coming towards us each day. Most of it is about us, without us, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: The Voice debate has put the worst of Australia on display. Indigenous people deserve better

image.altText: Meg Southcombe on The Drum panel.

items.synopsis: In a 56-second clip, student teacher and mental health advocate Meg Southcombe sums up why educators need more respect. Her words are resonating across the internet.

title.children: 'I'll yell it louder for the people at the back': Meg called for more respect for teachers. Her words have struck a nerve

image.altText: Mitchell Starc lays on the ground.

items.synopsis: Six dropped catches and some inept batting leaves Australia with a 0-2 record at the Cricket World Cup.

title.children: Aussies grass six catches in humiliating defeat to South Africa at Cricket World Cup

image.altText: A blister pack of the antibiotic doxycycline, which is used to treat a range of conditions from acne to cholera.

items.synopsis: Australia's leading sexual health experts say taking a drug known as "doxy-PEP" after unprotected sex could help curb rising rates of syphilis, but there's a big catch associated with antibiotic use.

title.children: There's a new kind of 'morning after' pill on the scene. But it's not to prevent pregnancies

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Friday, October 13.

title.children: Referendum poll looms as Yes and No campaigns make last-ditch efforts to convince voters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We will be bringing you the latest developments on the Voice to Parliament referendum as they happen today. Yesterday, the AEC warned against wearing "campaign material" to the polls after a Indigenous elder was turned away from voting over his Yes shirt. Independent senator Lidia Thorpe said a No win would be a "victory" for the Blak Sovereign Movement. NT opposition leader Lia Finocchiaro said alternatives to the Voice were being prepared in case the vote falls down. Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to our live coverage

children.content: We will be bringing you the latest developments on the
Voice to Parliament
referendum as they happen today.
Yesterday, the
AEC warned against wearing "campaign material" to the polls
after a Indigenous elder was turned away from voting over his Yes shirt.
Independent senator
Lidia Thorpe
said a No win would be a "victory" for the Blak Sovereign Movement.
NT opposition leader
Lia Finocchiaro
said alternatives to the Voice were being prepared in case the vote falls down.
Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.

image.altText: Black letters that spell out PwC on a white wall with red, orange and yellow graphic squares above the letter C.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant PwC is accused of misleading the Senate after revelations it planned to sell its consultancy business at the same time it pushed back against the idea in evidence to a separate inquiry in 2019.

title.children: PwC caught out after telling Senate it was against 'separating' its businesses while looking for a seller in private

image.altText: A map of Australia electorates divided between orange and purple.

items.synopsis: The rules that determine how the Voice referendum will be run were written more than 100 years ago.

title.children: In referendums, not all votes are created equal

image.altText: A large concrete police station with a sign saying Mt Isa Police Headquarters.

items.synopsis: The Mount Isa man has his charge upgraded from grievous bodily harm to murder after the other man dies from his injuries.

title.children: Man charged with murder after 18yo dies in outback hospital

image.altText: A purple-blue backlit desk featuring multiple people playing games on keyboards.

items.synopsis: What are the climate consequences of developing video games? When an independent studio made its sixth game, it decided to find out.

title.children: 'No video games on a dead planet': New report reveals carbon cost of game development

image.altText: A grahpic of coloured question marks surrounding a black and white photo of parliament house.

items.synopsis: One of Australia's leading constitutional law experts believes the Voice referendum could be the last time Australians vote to change the constitution, after more than 12 months of campaigning from both sides of politics.

title.children: Constitutional expert believes Voice vote could be the last referendum held in Australia

image.altText: A porcupine using its spikes to defend itself against a leopard

items.synopsis: An image of a mysterious, shimmering golden horseshoe crab, one of almost 50,000 entries from 95 countries, takes first place in the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition.

title.children: Fighting goats and a hippo nursery: The winning images from the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition

image.altText: An outback setting

items.synopsis: A decrease in the quality of phosphate being mined overseas and growing investor interest in ethical projects are driving miners into Australia's largely untapped reserves.

title.children: Mining to begin on Australia's biggest phosphate deposits amid global demand for fertiliser

image.altText: Bright yellow orange sky with Uluru in foreground.

items.synopsis: The two New South Wales men, who claim to be sovereign citizens, were fined almost $9,000 each for entering and vandalising the prohibited site.

title.children: 'No shame': Pair found guilty of using oily handprints to damage sacred Uluru cave art

image.altText: GAZA ABC photo

items.synopsis: The death toll in Gaza is rising and vital supplies are running low. Follow live

title.children: Death toll in Gaza rises to more than 1,500 as Israel masses tanks on border

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The death toll in Gaza has risen to1,537, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. This includes 500 children and 276 women. It says 6,612 have been injured in Israeli air strikes on the blockaded enclave since Saturday. The Palestine Red Crescent Society says parademics has recorded 12 violations that resideluted in the death of four paramedics and the injury of five others. It says seven ambulances experienced damage and significant damage was inflicted on the association's headquarters in northern Gaza and the emergency operations room. Israel's public broadcaster Kan said theIsraeli deathtollhad risen to more than 1,300. Most were civilians gunned down in their homes, on the streets or at a dance party.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Death toll rises to more than 1,500 in Gaza, health ministry says

children.content: The death toll in Gaza has risen to1,537, according to the
Gaza
Health Ministry.
This includes 500 children and 276 women.
It says 6,612 have been injured in Israeli air strikes on the blockaded enclave since Saturday.
The
Palestine Red Crescent Society
says parademics has recorded 12 violations that resideluted in the death of four paramedics and the injury of five others.
It says seven ambulances experienced damage and significant damage was inflicted on the association's headquarters in northern Gaza and the emergency operations room.
Israel's public broadcaster Kan said theIsraeli deathtollhad risen to more than
Most were civilians gunned down in their homes, on the streets or at a dance party.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The prime minister has confirmed 220 Australians will be onboard the first Qantas plane scheduled to leave Israel in the early hours of Saturday morning. The plane is set to touch down in Tel Aviv late tonight before flying out in the early hours of tomorrow morning to London. Qantas will also send a second plane to Israel at a later date. The flights are available for Australian citizens who can't book a commercial ticket and are free of charge. Speaking on Channel Nine, Anthony Albanese says Qantas is now working out logistics to get Australians from London back home. "Qantas are also putting in place the logistical exercise to then fly from London back to Australia via Singapore, it's being put in place as we speak," he says. A third private charter flight has been organised for next week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: First Qantas repatriation flight for Australians to arrive in Tel Aviv tonight

children.content: The prime minister has confirmed 220 Australians will be onboard the first Qantas plane scheduled to leave Israel in the early hours of Saturday morning.
The plane is set to touch down in Tel Aviv late tonight before flying out in the early hours of tomorrow morning to London.
Qantas will also send a second plane to Israel at a later date.
The flights are available for Australian citizens who can't book a commercial ticket and are free of charge.
Speaking on Channel Nine, Anthony Albanese says Qantas is now working out logistics to get Australians from London back home.
"Qantas are also putting in place the logistical exercise to then fly from London back to Australia via Singapore, it's being put in place as we speak," he says.
A third private charter flight has been organised for next week.

image.altText: premier gesturing as she speaks, behind a lecturn

items.synopsis: Those who display, distribute or publish a banned symbol — and cause others to feel harassed or offended — could face up to six months' jail.

title.children: Nazi flags to be banned under new Queensland hate symbol laws. Here's what's changing

image.altText: A computer-generated image of three towers planned for Surfers Paradise.

items.synopsis: The project is expected to include more than 1,000 homes and a childcare centre.

title.children: Surfers Paradise triple tower complex gets green light from council

image.altText: A group of Socceroos players in white tops stand in a room with three current and former Australian coaches.

items.synopsis: Graham Arnold calls in the "dream team" of Ange Postecoglou and Guus Hiddink to address the Socceroos before they take on England at Wembley.

title.children: Ange and Guus rev up the Socceroos before Wembley clash with England

image.altText: A view of a narrow underground tunnel.

items.synopsis: An Israeli invasion of Gaza will face an enemy that has built a formidable armoury, dug a vast tunnel network to evade attackers and shown in past ground wars it can exact a heavier toll on Israeli troops each time.

title.children: To defeat Hamas the Israeli military will likely have to conquer tunnels they call the 'Gaza metro'

image.altText: A man lifts a trophy after winning a rugby league match

items.synopsis: Australian coach Mal Meninga is doing all he can to restore the prestige of the Kangaroos jersey, but the future of the green and gold is up in the air.

title.children: The Kangaroos jersey has a glorious past but it's future seems uncertain

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: The latest data out of the US shows inflation is sticking around, which is leading investors to worry that regulators there will start raising rates again soon. Meanwhile, experts warn that if the Israel-Gaza war escalates it has the "potential to certainly derail markets". Read all about it as it happens on our live blog.

title.children: Inflation data reignites interest rate fears on Wall Street and ASX, while Israel-Gaza war sparks recession fears

image.altText: A plane flying towards the sun.

items.synopsis: Aviation emissions have almost doubled since 2000 and in 2018 reached 1 billion tonnes. Climate Action Tracker rates the industry's climate performance as critically insufficient, despite the fact Australian airlines are introducing newer, more fuel efficient aircraft into their fleets.

title.children: Flying less and charging more are ways to reduce airlines' carbon emissions, but would travellers get on board?

image.altText: Thick black and grey smoke rises above multistorey buildings following an airstrike.

items.synopsis: Fears are widening that the Israel-Gaza conflict could spread further and create more volatility for investors and the global economy, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

image.altText: Fire crews stand in front of an overturned bus beside a road.

items.synopsis: The review was conducted after the Hunter Valley bus crash that killed 10 people earlier this year. The NSW government has vowed to implement all five of the recommendations made and will launch a new seatbelt safety campaign immediately.

title.children: Safety report issued after tragic wedding party bus crash that shocked the nation

image.altText: A young boy holds a sign that says Save My Childcare.

items.synopsis: Victorian councils are increasingly leaving childcare services to the private sector, with a number of local governments saying they can no longer afford to run early learning facilities.

title.children: As costs mount, more Melbourne councils are leaving childcare to the private sector

image.altText: A range of olive oils sit on a supermarket shelf.

items.synopsis: The largest producer of olive oil in Australia says it is delighted by the support it is getting from Australian consumers as prices for international competitors rise.

title.children: How Aussie extra-virgin olive oil is bucking an international trend

image.altText: A close-up of Shannon Fentiman looking serious

items.synopsis: Shannon Fentiman told parliament the young woman attended the Rockhampton emergency department in early August for a forensic examination following the alleged rape but "did not receive the timely compassionate, trauma-informed care she was entitled to".

title.children: Queensland health minister apologises to alleged rape victim over inadequate care

image.altText: Man with a cap waves a rate notice.

items.synopsis: Ratepayers across Australia have copped stiff rate bills this year as cash-strapped councils struggle to keep pace with escalating costs.

title.children: Could the voting power of millions of stressed ratepayers decide the next federal election?

image.altText: SCAM duo

items.synopsis: A regional bank manager and her staff stepped in when an elderly local couple were being swindled by brazen scammers to the tune of $10,000.

title.children: 'It all looked unnatural': Small-town bank saves couple from losing $10,000 to brazen scammers

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi getting into a car

items.synopsis: The singer-songwriter broke down as she told the court her mother convinced her not to trust anyone with her millions at the height of her career.

title.children: Vanessa Amorosi breaks down in court and says a property dispute with her mother started a family 'war'

image.altText: Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith pose on the red carpet during the Oscars.

items.synopsis: In a tell-all book and interview, Jada Pinkett Smith says she's still technically Will Smith's wife, but they've been separated for seven years.

title.children: Jada Pinkett Smith says she and Will Smith were separated when the Oscars slap happened
